prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. For a nonnegative integer $n$, let $r_9(n)$ stand for the remainder left when $n$ is divided by $9.$ For example, $r_9(25)=7.$

What is the $22^{\text{nd}}$ entry in an ordered list of all nonnegative integers $n$ that satisfy $$r_9(5n)\le 4~?$$(Note that the first entry in this list is $0$.)
solution:
The condition $r_9(5n)\le 4$ can also be stated as $``5n\equiv 0,1,2,3,\text{ or }4\pmod 9."$'

We can then restate that condition again by multiplying both sides by $2:$ $$10n \equiv 0,2,4,6,\text{ or }8\pmod 9.$$This step is reversible (since $2$ has an inverse modulo $9$). Thus, it neither creates nor removes solutions. Moreover, the left side reduces to $n$ modulo $9,$ giving us the precise solution set $$n \equiv 0,2,4,6,\text{ or }8\pmod 9.$$We wish to determine the $22^{\text{nd}}$ nonnegative integer in this solution set. The first few solutions follow this pattern: $$\begin{array}{c c c c c}
0 & 2 & 4 & 6 & 8 \\
9 & 11 & 13 & 15 & 17 \\
18 & 20 & 22 & 24 & 26 \\
27 & 29 & 31 & 33 & 35 \\
36 & 38 & \cdots
\end{array}$$The $22^{\text{nd}}$ solution is $\boxed{38}.$
gpt_response:
To solve this problem, we first note that the remainders when $n$ is divided by $9$ cycle every $9$ numbers. Since $r_9(5n) = r_9(5(n+9))$ for any integer $n$, we can see that the remainders when $5n$ is divided by $9$ also cycle every $9$ numbers.

Since $r_9(5n) \leq 4$, we are looking for the integers $n$ such that the remainder when $5n$ is divided by $9$ is $0, 1, 2, 3,$ or $4.$ These correspond to the values of $n$ where $5n$ is congruent to $0, 1, 2, 3,$ or $4$ modulo $9.$ In other words, we are looking for the numbers $n$ such that $$5n \equiv 0, 1, 2, 3, \text{ or } 4 \pmod{9}$$

By examining the possible remainders when $5n$ is divided by $9$, we can write down the first $9$ possible remainders:

$5, 1, 6, 2, 7, 3, 8, 4, 0$

Therefore, the ordered list of all nonnegative integers that satisfy $r_9(5n) \leq 4$ would be the sequence formed by repeatedly cycling through the above list. The $22^{\text{nd}}$ entry in this list corresponds to the number that is at position $22$ when considering this cycle. 

Since $22$ is congruent to $4$ modulo $9$ and the remainder when $22$ is divided by $9$ is $4$, the $22^{\text{nd}}$ entry in the list will be the $4^{\text{th}}$ entry in the cycle of remainders. Therefore, the $22^{\text{nd}}$ number in the list would be $4 \times 9 = 36.$

So, the $22^{\text{nd}}$ entry in the ordered list of all nonnegative integers satisfying $r_9(5n) \leq 4$ is $\boxed{36}$.
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response 38?: To solve this problem, we first note that the remainders when $n$ is divided by $9$ cycle every $9$ numbers. Since $r_9(5n) = r_9(5(n+9))$ for any integer $n$, we can see that the remainders when $5n$ is divided by $9$ also cycle every $9$ numbers.

Since $r_9(5n) \leq 4$, we are looking for the integers $n$ such that the remainder when $5n$ is divided by $9$ is $0, 1, 2, 3,$ or $4.$ These correspond to the values of $n$ where $5n$ is congruent to $0, 1, 2, 3,$ or $4$ modulo $9.$ In other words, we are looking for the numbers $n$ such that $$5n \equiv 0, 1, 2, 3, \text{ or } 4 \pmod{9}$$

By examining the possible remainders when $5n$ is divided by $9$, we can write down the first $9$ possible remainders:

$5, 1, 6, 2, 7, 3, 8, 4, 0$

Therefore, the ordered list of all nonnegative integers that satisfy $r_9(5n) \leq 4$ would be the sequence formed by repeatedly cycling through the above list. The $22^{\text{nd}}$ entry in this list corresponds to the number that is at position $22$ when considering this cycle. 

Since $22$ is congruent to $4$ modulo $9$ and the remainder when $22$ is divided by $9$ is $4$, the $22^{\text{nd}}$ entry in the list will be the $4^{\text{th}}$ entry in the cycle of remainders. Therefore, the $22^{\text{nd}}$ number in the list would be $4 \times 9 = 36.$

So, the $22^{\text{nd}}$ entry in the ordered list of all nonnegative integers satisfying $r_9(5n) \leq 4$ is $\boxed{36}$.
